div.p:
The following is a literal translation of a letter from
Humboldt to Lieut. J. M. Gilliss, at Washington,
author of the work on Chili, recently published by
order of Congress. The letter bearn date—

I need words to express to you how much I have
been touched by the noble token of remembrance you
have sent me—the admirable volumes you have pub-
lished on Chili and the magnificent Cordilleras bor-
dering it. In one respect your work marks an epoch,
for, at the time of Bouguer and La Condamine, sci-
ence was less advanced, and instruments and methods
less perfected. You have enriched, at the same time,
Astronomy, Geography, Geology, and, to some extent,
descriptive Natural History. A work which has
been brought out in so splendid a manner, well mer-
its the title of a “Naval Astronomical Expedition of
the United States.” After you, it honors the Gov-
ernment which undertook and fostered it.

I have read it at night, page by page, and always
with increasing interest; and, although your gener-
ous present reached me at the most disturbed period
of my life, when my health is no little suffering, I
have been able to enjoy it and express to you my ad-
miration for a work greatly superior to every thing
published upon South America since the time of Bou-
guer and La Condamine. Varied in its delineations,
rich in celestial, magnetical, geographical, and histori-
cal facts, for it all I need a leisure which is not accord-
ed to me. I should limit myself to profit by your
observations, and, offering to you for them the most
cordial expressions of gratitude, I hope to live long
enough to see the next volume.

Tell me, will it contain the extensive astronomical
observations for the parallax—the immediate object
of your important expedition—your magnetical ob-
servations (the intensity greatly interests me from my
own investigations in Peru long ago)—the review of
the Southern heavens; and your report on the bril-
liancy of Eta Argus, which you saw as luminous as
Canopus?

Although I have passed a portion of my life in
measuring them, I do not regard the phenomenon of
the absolute height of mountains as one of great mo-
ment; yet, when called upon to answer the question,
Which is the highest mountain of America? I should
be able to give the numbers that are believed to
be the most exact. Is the highest mountain, then,
Aconcagua, Sahama, or your Tupungato, in latitude
33° 22′ S.? In the table on page 13 you state it to be
22,458 feet, and on the map from the survey of M.
Pissis opposite page 48, only 22,016 feet. Which of
these numbers seems to you the most probable? The
trigonometrical measures seem equally dependent on
barometrical valuations of the base.

Do you consider the result for Aconcagua by M.
Pissis, 22,301 feet, as more reliable than that given
us by Fitzroy, who made it 21,767 Paris feet? though,
according to the correction by Pentland we should
have 22,431 Paris feet. Kellet found Aconcagua to
have a height of 21,564 Parisian or 23,004 English
feet. To which of these determinations do you give
preference?

Chimborazo also should be re-measured. From
my observations made at Riobamba-Nuevo, I believe
its elevation to be 20,100 Paris feet. Kunchingunga
is 4406 toises. The brothers Schlagintwert have been
on the slopes of Ibi-Gamen in Thibet, and found Si-
berian shells at an elevation of 20,886 French feet!
Accept, respected friend, my kind regards,
